Yup. Dead on exactly right. Very simple math for the individual to do BTW.

But very very difficult math for the Gooberm$nt to do.

"Instead, most people on welfare get off in a hurry taking whatever job they can find."

Please cite the source.
According to the Cato Institute, wage equivalent value of benefits for a mother and two children (collecting benefits) ranged from $60,590 in Hawaii to $11,150 in Idaho.

I don't think introduction of the basic benefit requires abolishing the minimum wage, why? And certainly getting rid of all the means-tested programs once the benefit  is established will be a huge step forward on a path to the fairer and less corrupt society. I don't have much hope for it, though...

If there was a program that would give Professor Mulligan 50% of what he presently earns while leaving him 100% free to do whatever he wants with his time, he would probably take that deal.  Wouldn't you?

Earl W. you make a specious assumption that a person who is not working while qualifying for assistance is "100% free to do whatever he wants with his time."

Living in poverty is living in a world of NO. Living in poverty is labor- and time-intensive and you are NOT free to do whatever you want with your time regardless of employment.

In this world:
many welfare benefits are conditional on going to meetings, evals, classes etc. and explaining your situation many times often in punitive and humiliating places

owning a car is expensive so you likely take public transit to get places. Even if your bus fare is free, it costs you hours of your life that you will never get back. If your kid needs daycare, you will wake them at 5 to be at an appointment by 9.

your choices are restricted - you can't buy TP or deodorant with SNAP. You can buy your kid a toy for their birthday if it's got food in it (like Easter toys). It's hard to haul groceries on an hourlong bus ride, so you choose processed food that's easy to carry and doesn't spoil/ melt quickly

you don't have much fun, because most fun costs too much. Occasional fast food & ice cream are (small) luxuries you can have. Redbox, network TV, gossip, and sex are cheap entertainment.

And in the end, you are doing all of this with less energy from low-quality food and fewer emotional and cognitive resources due to constant stress and public vilification from Earl W and his ilk.

ErinA:  Did you read the article?  Many people who draw unemployment compensation are not in grinding poverty.  Examples include seasonal employees, husbands or wives with a working spouse, and retirees or near-retirees.  During the period of time for which they can receive unemployment, the choice is work at "X" per hour and give up the value of the leisure time foregone or collect "X/2" per hour and keep the time to enjoy as they see fit.

I am yet to meet or hear about a person comparing job offers from companies to food stamps. The writer should seriously give up their job and enjoy the welfare state benefits he claims are competing with private companies. Please spend a year in public housing on food stamps and then let us know how that compares to a full time job that pays above poverty level wages.

"I would prefer to have a private email account for which I would pay a reasonable fee."

So, what's stopping you? Over 15 years ago I registered a domain, mainly to get an e-mail address not tied to any particular ISP. I pay $10 a month plus whatever they charge for the yearly domain registration. I have a handful of different e-mail addresses (mainly for sorting reasons) and complete control over everything. And there's no spam inserted in incoming or outgoing messages.

I honestly don't understand why anyone would rely on a free e-mail service, especially when that provider is scanning your messages for ad targeting. I _really_ don't understand why any small business would think that a gmail.com e-mail address is somehow "professional."
Yes, a 'die in place' will be the best immigration policy. Once established the current legal system will take care of our need for immigrants, legal ones only.

blackmamba:

So according to the NYT, illegal aliens have magically become "unauthorized immigrants", who have been subjected to "overzealous, unconstitutional enforcement", "stranded by congressional inaction", and will be brought "into line with its mission". This English language reconstruction, and the next big thing set up for Capitol Hill to put on their New Year resolution political agenda, complete with this editorial, which attempts to change the facts to suit their agenda while assuming that on Christmas Night decent Americans are asleep at the wheel.

Congress will eventually address the issue of illegal aliens, after they have first considered the mayhem which Mr Mayorkas has left in his wake; many millions of applicants world wide who wait patiently in line to come to the US legally, complying with US regulations, to the proverbial "T", while other millions showing total contempt for the US, and our laws, pour across US borders whether on foot or by overstaying visas.

And the NYT sees no difference in the desire of the legal, perfectly compliant legal immigrant, who waits patiently in hope of permission to comply, and the flood of illegal aliens who have neither legal standing to enter the US, nor even the remotest Constitutional protection.

As a proud American, a legal immigrant in 1962, who is in debt to the US for the opportunities proffered, granted and fulfilled, the welfare of legal immigrants is the issue. Illegal aliens have no standing except to get in line.

Anything created by man is inherently flawed, as man is inherently flawed, but the constitution remains the greatest document ever written by man. And to say that it is "a work in progress" is to double-down on that progressive meme that it is a "living, breathing document". It is no such thing. It was designed to protect the individual from an oppressive federal leviathan.

Madison and the other Founding Fathers would be appalled and dismayed at what Wilson, FDR, LBJ, Bush and Obama have wrought.

The contradiction you point out only goes to serve how those who subscribe to "originalism" are, basically, frauds, using that doctrine as a subterfuge to support a point of view that is contrary to the true meaning of the Constitution.

@Cjmesq0
The Founders would've VEHEMENTLY disagreed with you.
"It was designed to protect the individual from an oppressive federal leviathan." <====this is NOT mutually exclusive of a document that was designed to be modified. Yes, they wanted to protect the colonies from centralized power, but ALSO to allow for the document to accommodate a future they knew they could not know themselves. In other words, they wanted it to be modifiable precisely BECAUSE they didn't want it to fail (as it nearly did, in the struggle against slavery). Since you admit that man is inherently flawed, which the Founders understood, it makes no sense to create a document that was not meant to be changed. That's why the process of adding amendments was built into it. If it wasn't meant to be there, it wouldn't be there.

PS: Its interesting that the only 'appalling' presidents you list are Democrats...Lincoln, the Republican, wasn't worthy of the cut?

Ms Greenhouse,

When you phrase things the way you did in showing that the 1787 version of the Constitution was seriously flawed, it's hard for me to understand why any Judge would ever want to be known as an "Originalist."

The question I ask is since when the mother is the sole custodian of her children in a marriage, and in a household shared by mother and father? Since when are the NY born US citizen husbands in the same household immune from US criminal charges from underpaid and overworked nanny?

It is obvious to me that the nanny felt isolated from her children whom she left behind in India, and was envious of Dr. Khobragade's professional career, and that she was contributing to her employer's success, while her own children lived with their father and grandparents in India. I am not aware of any rant against immigrants -- that is against those who enter this country legally, under quota, with the intention of becoming law abiding permanent residents. I do not hear it where i live. Neither do I hear anger or alarm expressed concerning those from foreign lands who come here on legal, time-limited visas -- as tourists, students or on work visas.

Hoards who brazenly cross our borders illegally are quite another matter. They do upset us. They are challenging our right to have national borders! We become upset as well when our government fails to take action against those who so brazenly challenge our right to have defensible borders and to define who may or may not cross them.

Historically, and everywhere in this world, such hoards have been called foreign invaders -- not immigrants. It is customary to evict them forcibly. Countries that do not take such defensive action, lose their existence and identity as sovereign nations. We wish to remain a sovereign nation.

I fail to grasp your analogy to discriminatory attitudes and actions taken against others, in the past, who have entered this country as invited, legal immigrants. Of course, that was wrong!

Opposition to illegal immigration is not equivalent to opposition to legal immigration. Given the current state of unemployment and debt within the country, a pragmatic approach to immigration is appropriate. We should seek to naturalize the best and the brightest. These immigrants have been proven to be drivers for the new world economy.

As noted by many, the number of low skilled jobs is diminishing and will not recover. The bulk of illegal immigrants have little education and poor language skills. If they are naturalized,they will join the large pool of unemployable folks who are destined to be wards of the state as they age.

We should not function as a social and financial relief valve for failed states.

@David Underwood: Please learn to read English, or at least to understand what the words mean before you participate in a conversation with grownups. I personally don't have personal experience of how things were in the Stone Age; you evidently do, otherwise you shouldn't be making comparisons.
For the same reason, I wouldn't allow myself to second-guess what people in the XIX century had to say about Irish or Italian immigrants: I wasn't born yet, and I'm not PC enough to assume if a statement is negative, it isn't true, or should be silenced.
As for today's brand of immigration, if you haven't noticed, things have changed. Our resources are strained, the economy isn't booming, and the country is pretty much full, as is the planet. Nobody's insulting immigrants in general; people (whom you obviously disagree with enough to slander) express a disagreement with foreign nationals disobeying our laws, reaping benefits, and deciding for us who enters the country. Nothing more.

The campaign against immigrants goes back a long way in our history, and it also had religious overtones.

As far back as 1845 it was written, "That foreigners provoked the jeremiad that a terrible moral crisis was threatening the nation. A new underslass wallowed in the same old old sins: they were lazy, violent, soaked i whiskey, and promiscuous. They wee worse than promiscuous , they were depraved-they stashed virgins in convents that American patriots occasionally burned to the ground. They drank,they fought, anti-immigration was the basis of the Know-Nothing Party .
(Hellfire Nation: pg 191-198)

This referred mostly to the Irish, but Italians were also subject to this kind of literatural abuse. So we see immigrants escaping poverty and starvation whom we know came and worked in the steel mills, on the railroads, being subjected to the same kind of invectives and slander we today about the immigrants from Mexico and Central America. And they took American jobs, that belonged to those who were already here. The only difference is there was no immigration laws as we have today, which were eventually made because of the Chinese who were brought here to build the Central Pacific RR.

So we see the anti-immigrant rants of the GOP and its evangelist philosophy repeating the sins of the past, they can not get beyond the stone age.

Thank you, Ms. Greenhouse, for publicizing the "Records of Rights" exhibit at the National Archives. It sounds like a superb exhibit.

The triumphal aspect of American constitutional democracy is that we continue to evolve and attempt to perfect our democracy. While I am disheartened by the current Roberts Court majority, I feel that the evolution of U.S. Constitutional law has, by in large, proceeded in the right direction since 1787. I hope that we continue to evolve to evolve toward a more perfect implementation of democracy.

Profits are up, but revenues are flat. Employers have used the crisis to (in their minds) clean house and get on a new basis for costs. However when demand comes back they will generally be unable to exploit that opportunity. In the tech sector where I work the crisis massively accelerated the trend for offshore. Employees with decades of experience and the inventiveness of western education have been replaced by people with little experience, impressive diplomas but due their rote-style of education have extremely low inventiveness compared to westerners.

Soon either we will hit a period of doldrums, where established players use their position to block change and continue their cost-cutting, or a time when startups fueled by layed-off workers will make big problems for the bean-counting firms who's main concern is trying to add pennies of earnings per share each quarter.

We are falling backwards to a feudal system of government and economy, where the serfs works simply to enrich the aristocracy. Our economy is hurting because not enough people have the disposable income to strengthen it. Unless the one percent wants to buy everybody a care, we need to make some more fundamental changes.

Two posts by Anandita just before yours contains answers to your comment. Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, 1963, was specifically agreed to by all the UN member nations so that a more muscular country does not impose its domestic laws on consular officials of less muscular countries. No scope for arrest unless she murdered somebody or is an imminent terrorist. If the U.S. did not like her, it should have simply expelled her from US soil.

You have stated the situation very precisely. When my neighbour sold his land next to my house, everyone of his household workers got a share of the sale proceeds. My gardener, three shifts of my watchmen, my dhobi, my front yard sweeper, and the young man who lives in a small quarter in my house and keeps an eye during my absence from the country expect to be paid a share of the sale price of my house whenever I sell it. They know one day I will sell it, or my children will inherit it, and they know how to get their share! By the way, we have no maid. After living for decades in USA, we learned to live without a maid.
If she couldn't afford a nanny or housekeeper at the U.S. legal minimum wage, then she should have lived without one like the vast majority of Americans do.

You obviously don't know U.S. rules for employment of domestic workers by diplomats. As a former consular officer I can tell you that you don't get a visa unless the diplomat employing you provides a contract stipulating a salary of at minimum wage plus room/board.

Rami - You have mistaken. You make it sound a if every second Indian home has a 12 year old working as a domestic help. Even if Indian laws are not very regularly enforced, generally people do not employ underage kids for domestic work - based on their own conscience.
It is rooted in the caste psychology - no qualms at mistreating the ones doing the lowest of tasks.
It's a deep seated inhumane and careless treatment of the domestic workers. It is appalling that in many Indian homes no one asks how the 12 year old working in their kitchen got there.

The Indian victims of Bhopal were ignored and neglected by their own Indian government, after being exploited, injured, and killed by "Americans" (as you put it.) If anything, Bhopal is just another illustration of the lack of respect for the rule of law in India, which is again rearing its head in this fiasco. The US is far from a perfect society, but the supremacy of law is one of its strongest features and indeed a core value of the American population. I only wish that the Indian government acted according to these same principles when it came to Bhopal. American executives should have been arrested and imprisoned, and Union Carbide's assets should have been seized and legal actions filed (in US courts if necessary) to adequately compensate the victims. That would have been the rule of law reigning supreme in India. But it does not reign supreme, so none of those things happen.

Here, again, we see a diplomat facing charges and being arrested just like any person would in the event of visa fraud being discovered by the US government. The fact that American law demands she be treated like anyone else, however, is shocking and even abhorrent to large sections of the Indian population. And that is tragic.

To me the AAP sterling performance in the recent Delhi election sends out a clear message, more so having read the following wonderful analysis by Malcolm Gladwell in David and Goliath: : Underdogs, Misfits, and the Art of Battling Giants.

• There is a set of advantages that have to do with material resources, and there is a set that have to do with the absence of material resources- and the reason underdogs win as often as they do is that the latter is sometimes every bit the equal of the former.

• Giants are not what we think they are. The same qualities that appear to give them strength are often the sources of great weakness.

• ..legitimacy is based on three things. First of all, the people who are asked to obey authority have to feel like they have a voice--that if they speak up, they will be heard. Second, the law has to be predictable. There has to be a reasonable expectation that the rules tomorrow are going to be roughly the same as the rules today. And third, the authority has to be fair. It can't treat one group differently from another.

• Much of what we consider valuable in our world arises out of (these) one-sided conflicts. Because the act of facing overwhelming odds, produces greatness and beauty..

A tragedy like this reminds me of the situation where people are continuously run down at an intersection and the government finally decides to install a traffic light.  Now they can say they have addressed the problem and then blame future accidents on the citizenry.   This is what I fear will happen in India: They have put up the traffic light but will they monitor and enforce it?
